introPages.title: What are phrasal verbs?
introPages.body:
Phrasal verbs are multi-word verbs: a main verb + one or two particles. The particle is a preposition or adverb that attaches to the verb. Together they form a single unit with a meaning that often differs from the verb alone.

Examples: look + into = investigate; give + up = stop trying; look + forward + to = anticipate.

The particle gives a clue to the meaning – it functions a bit like a prefix (e.g. up often suggests completion; out can suggest distribution or removal). But each phrasal verb must be learned as a whole; the particle is fixed for that meaning.

introPages.title: Types of phrasal verbs
introPages.body:
Transitive vs intransitive: Some phrasal verbs take an object (carry out a survey), others do not (give up – we give up something, but the engine gave up needs no object).

Separable vs inseparable: With some transitive phrasal verbs, the object can go between the verb and the particle (turn off the light = turn the light off). With others, the particle must stay next to the verb (look into the matter – not look the matter into).

Two particles: Some phrasal verbs have two particles: look forward to, put up with, get away with.

introPages.title: Particles and meaning
introPages.body:
Common particles: up, down, in, out, on, off, away, back, through, over, for, with, about, into.

They often suggest direction or aspect: up (completion, increase), down (reduce), out (distribution, elimination), off (departure, removal). But the exact meaning depends on the verb – learn each phrasal verb as a unit.

introPages.title: In Part 2 and this programme
introPages.body:
In Part 2, the gap often needs the particle that completes a phrasal verb. Look at the verb before the gap – does it form a known phrasal verb?

For a fuller list of phrasal verbs and their meanings, see the phrasal verb list and dictionary elsewhere in this programme – in the Reference section and in the Practice materials. Use those resources to learn and check which particle goes with which verb.

introPages.title: Tips for the gap
introPages.body:
• Identify the verb immediately before the gap.
  • Ask: does this verb form a phrasal verb? What particle completes it?
  • Use the sentence meaning – which particle makes sense?
  • Some verbs take different particles for different meanings: take off (leave/remove), take up (start), take on (accept).
  • Consult the phrasal verb list in this programme when in doubt.

mcQuiz.question: In look ___ the problem (investigate), which particle fits?
In carry ___ a survey (perform), which particle fits?
In give ___ smoking (stop), which particle fits?
mcQuiz.explanation: Give up = stop trying, abandon a habit.

mcQuiz.question: In set ___ a business (establish), which particle fits?
In find ___ the truth (discover), which particle fits?
In deal ___ the situation (handle), which particle fits?
In take ___ a new hobby (start), which particle fits?

shortQuestions.question: We need to look up the complaint.
accepted: we need to look into the complaint
shortQuestions.explanation: Look into = investigate. Look up = search for information (e.g. in a dictionary).

shortQuestions.question: They carried on a survey last year.
accepted: they carried out a survey last year
shortQuestions.explanation: Carry out = perform, do. Carry on = continue.

shortQuestions.question: He gave in smoking.
shortQuestions.explanation: Give up = stop, abandon a habit. Give in = yield, surrender.

shortQuestions.question: She set out a company in 2020.
accepted: she set up a company in 2020
shortQuestions.explanation: Set up = establish, create. Set out = begin a journey, or explain.

shortQuestions.question: We found in what happened.
shortQuestions.explanation: Find out = discover. Find in is not a phrasal verb for this meaning.

shortQuestions.question: I'll deal about the matter.
shortQuestions.explanation: Deal with = handle, manage. Deal about is wrong.

shortQuestions.question: It depends from the weather.
shortQuestions.explanation: Depend on = rely on, be determined by. Depend from is wrong.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Why is it important to look at the verb before the gap when guessing a phrasal verb particle?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: The particle is fixed for each phrasal verb. The verb tells you which phrasal verb is needed; the surrounding words (object, context) tell you the meaning and thus which particle fits.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Give three phrasal verbs that mean 'continue' and use each in a short example.
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: Carry on – We must carry on. / Keep on – He kept on working. / Go on – Please go on with your story.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Explain the difference between take off, take up, and take on.
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: Take off = leave (plane), remove (clothes). Take up = start (hobby, space). Take on = accept (work, responsibility), employ.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: In put ___ the meeting (postpone), which particle fits? Why?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: Put off. Put off = postpone, delay. The particle is fixed for this meaning.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Name three phrasal verbs commonly used in formal or academic contexts.
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: e.g. carry out (research), look into (matter), set up (system), find out (information), deal with (issue), consist of (parts), result in (outcome).
